repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Fixes #5634.
Fixes #5697 (from a Cython point of view; Numpy still includes stuff that isn't limited API compatible).

I've done two things:
1. Added two values of check_size to "opaque" and "opaque_in_limited_api". These don't check the object size at import (which avoids need to do sizeof on opaque types). However they're restricted so they can't be used as a way of disabling the size check.
2. Added a compiler directive for cdef functions that wraps them in an `#if` guard. It's mainly for our internal use so undocumented but I'm fairly relaxed if people find and use it.

With these I can get all of the pxd files (except cpython.array.pxd) so that they can be be cimported in limited API mode. Of course, much of them won't work, but it won't present a compile error unless used. Which at least means that people can use the bits that do work.

comment_data.body: We're probably not the only ones who provide declarations for builtin types, so rather than adding a new option specifically for the Limited API (which is really a backend, not a frontend thing), we should see if we can exclude all types defined in the `__builtin__` module from the size check when compiling for the Limited API.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -12,14 +13,20 @@ cdef extern from "Python.h":
     # PyComplexObject
     # This subtype of PyObject represents a Python complex number object.
 
-    ctypedef class __builtin__.complex [object PyComplexObject]:
+    # It actually isn't even opaque in the limited API - it just isn't present. However, "opaque"
+    # removes enough code that it isn't a compile error
+    ctypedef class __builtin__.complex [object PyComplexObject, check_size opaque_in_limited_api]:

comment_data.body:
Maybe(!), we should ignore `inline` methods/properties defined on builtin types in the Limited API? I'm not sure, and it's somewhat of a stretch in motivating it, but they seem a bit more likely to get in the way on a cross-version Stable ABI build (although that's not entirely the only reason for the Limited API), and also more likely to not work at all, as in this case. The way I read them, they are really a performance feature. If they only override existing Python API (and we could even check that and restrict their removal to this case), then there's not much of a reason for them in the Limited API.

So, check if they override existing attributes/methods and then discard them in the Limited API?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -12,14 +13,20 @@ cdef extern from "Python.h":
     # PyComplexObject
     # This subtype of PyObject represents a Python complex number object.
 
-    ctypedef class __builtin__.complex [object PyComplexObject]:
+    # It actually isn't even opaque in the limited API - it just isn't present. However, "opaque"
+    # removes enough code that it isn't a compile error
+    ctypedef class __builtin__.complex [object PyComplexObject, check_size opaque_in_limited_api]:
         cdef Py_complex cval
 
+        # unavailable in limited API
         @property
+        @_cython.c_compile_guard("!CYTHON_COMPILING_IN_LIMITED_API")

comment_data.body:
I'm not quite sure about this.

> The way I read them, they [cdef inline properties] are really a performance feature. If they only override existing Python API (and we could even check that and restrict their removal to this case), then there's not much of a reason for them in the Limited API.

Yes. The difficulty is disabling them in the Limited API without blocking access to the Python API. I can't see a good way of doing that.

------------------------------------

I've removed the changes in datetime.pxd since almost the whole thing was disabled in the Limited API so I think it's best to have a warning and give up.

That leaves:

* `real`/`imag` in `complex.pxd`
* A couple of inline module-scoped functions in `contextvar.pxd`.

I think the module-scoped functions mean "ignore inline methods/properties defined on builtin types" wouldn't really work.

So the options are:
* Do something similar to what I've done.
* Rewrite them to work with the Limited API. For the complex ones, it'd be hard to make it truly `noexcept`. The contextvar ones would just have to use the Python API

I'm not sure which is best.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -12,14 +13,20 @@ cdef extern from "Python.h":
     # PyComplexObject
     # This subtype of PyObject represents a Python complex number object.
 
-    ctypedef class __builtin__.complex [object PyComplexObject]:
+    # It actually isn't even opaque in the limited API - it just isn't present. However, "opaque"
+    # removes enough code that it isn't a compile error
+    ctypedef class __builtin__.complex [object PyComplexObject, check_size opaque_in_limited_api]:
         cdef Py_complex cval
 
+        # unavailable in limited API
         @property
+        @_cython.c_compile_guard("!CYTHON_COMPILING_IN_LIMITED_API")

comment_data.body: @scoder can you have another look at this?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -12,14 +13,20 @@ cdef extern from "Python.h":
     # PyComplexObject
     # This subtype of PyObject represents a Python complex number object.
 
-    ctypedef class __builtin__.complex [object PyComplexObject]:
+    # It actually isn't even opaque in the limited API - it just isn't present. However, "opaque"
+    # removes enough code that it isn't a compile error
+    ctypedef class __builtin__.complex [object PyComplexObject, check_size opaque_in_limited_api]:
         cdef Py_complex cval
 
+        # unavailable in limited API
         @property
+        @_cython.c_compile_guard("!CYTHON_COMPILING_IN_LIMITED_API")

comment_data.body: This is implied by the default value.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -350,6 +351,7 @@ class DEFER_ANALYSIS_OF_ARGUMENTS:
     'dataclasses.dataclass': DEFER_ANALYSIS_OF_ARGUMENTS,
     'dataclasses.field': DEFER_ANALYSIS_OF_ARGUMENTS,
     'embedsignature.format': one_of('c', 'clinic', 'python'),
+    'c_compile_guard': str,

comment_data.body:
> I've removed the changes in datetime.pxd since almost the whole thing was disabled in the Limited API so I think it's best to have a warning and give up.

A warning seems ok here. It might be annoying for some, but then the best solution is to extract the C-API usages into a separate module that gets optionally built and imported when not using the Limited API. So there are still ways to write code for both targets.

> A couple of inline module-scoped functions in `contextvar.pxd`.

There's already a verbatim code section at the top of the file that (stupidly) defines `PyContextVar_Get()` in older Python versions that lack it. We could reuse that for the Limited API to make it compile and add a warning as a comment that the contextvars C-API simply isn't available there. That would at least allow users to write code that uses the C-API if available and fall back to `import contextvars` otherwise.

We could also turn the macro into an inline function and then issue an actual Python warning if it gets called. That would help making users more aware of a problem in their code.

> real/imag in complex.pxd

Since these are Cython inline properties (and not Python properties), we could use a C inline function for the struct access that calls `PyObject_GetAttr()` in the Limited API.

The `noexcept` gets in the way then, though… but since failures should not occur in practice, we could still keep it and live with the "unraisable exception"…
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -12,14 +13,20 @@ cdef extern from "Python.h":
     # PyComplexObject
     # This subtype of PyObject represents a Python complex number object.
 
-    ctypedef class __builtin__.complex [object PyComplexObject]:
+    # It actually isn't even opaque in the limited API - it just isn't present. However, "opaque"
+    # removes enough code that it isn't a compile error
+    ctypedef class __builtin__.complex [object PyComplexObject, check_size opaque_in_limited_api]:
         cdef Py_complex cval
 
+        # unavailable in limited API
         @property
+        @_cython.c_compile_guard("!CYTHON_COMPILING_IN_LIMITED_API")

commit.message:
Allow cimport of cpython in the limited API

Fixes #5634.
Fixes #5697 (from a Cython point of view; Numpy still includes
stuff that isn't limited API compatible).

I've done two things:
1. Added two values of check_size to "opaque" and
   "opaque_in_limited_api". These don't check the object size at
   import (which avoids need to do sizeof on opaque types). However
   they're restricted so they can't be used as a way of disabling
   the size check.
2. Added a compiler directive for cdef functions that wraps them
   in an `#if` guard. It's mainly for our internal use so undocumented
   but I'm fairly relaxed if people find and use it.

With these I can get all of the pxd files (except cpython.array.pxd)
so that they can be be cimported in limited API mode. Of course,
much of them won't work, but it won't present a compile error
unless used. Which at least means that people can use the bits that
do work.
Make size and alignment 1 to avoid division errors

milestone.description:
* Remove code for Python 2 and Python < 3.7.
* Integrate better with Python 3.
* Improve support for the Limited API.
* Start supporting GIL-free Python 3.13.
* Support the Py3.13 `sys.monitoring` API.
* Support and use `am_send` for coroutines.

title: Allow cimport of cpython in the limited API
